questions.text: All the following are proposed mechanisms of beta 2 agonists in bronchial asthma EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Proposed mechanisms of beta 2 agonists:

Direct bronchodilation: (Bronchodilatory effect)

  1. Activation of Gs – adenylyl cyclase – cAMP-PKA pathway (Direct pathway of bronchodilation)

Indirect mechanisms: (Bronchoprotective effect)

  1. Prevention of mediator release from isolated human lung mast cells
  2. Prevention of microvascular leakage and thus the development of bronchial mucosal edema after exposure to mediators (like histamine, LTD4 and PGD2)
  3. Increased ion transport across airway epithelium (Enhances mucociliary clearance)
  4. Reduction in neurotransmission in human airway cholinergic nerves by action at presynaptic beta2 receptors to inhibit Ach release.

questions.text: If a case of negligence against a doctor has already been decided in one court, the patient cannot start fresh proceeding in another court, the doctrine applicable is:
questions.solution:
Res Judicata (the thing has already been decided)- If a case of negligence against a doctor has already been decided in one court, the patient cannot start fresh proceeding in another court. But appeal to higher court is allowed

Other choices:

1) Res ipsa loquitur ('the thing speaks for itself') means that nature of injury to patient is such that it in itself proves that Doctor was negligent. The patient does not have to prove anything further. Here the onus to disprove the negligence will lie with doctor. E.g. scissors left in Abdomen is an obvious negligence on the part of Doctors and other medical staff involved

2) Res gestae: Involuntary acts or statements made at the time of offence. These are not planned but forced from the individual by the heat of the moment. Hence, they are considered valid evidence. E.g. If A hears that B is running violently and shouting that C has stabbed him. Apart from being a “hear say evidence” as A hears B, it is also “res gestae” since it was made by B in the heat of moment.

3) Res Integra: An entirely new matter. Those points of law which have not yet been decided.

questions.text: A patient gets such lesions while doing exercising and on exposure to sunlight. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
• Cholinergic urticaria is a type of physical urticaria.
  • It manifests as multiple, small, 2 to 3 mm red hives on the upper trunk and arms, although it can occur from the neck to the thighs.
  • These hives appear in response to a rise in body temperature from exercise, overheating, or stress.
  • Usually, the hives develop within 2 to 20 minutes after the body temperature rises, although they can take up to an hour to occur.
  • They cause itching, tingling, burning, and warmth of the skin.
  • The hives last for minutes to hours with an average of 30 minutes.
  • It is believed that histamine is released in response to stimulation by the parasympathetic nervous system.
  • Cholinergic urticaria is diagnosed by history and reproducing the hives under certain conditions.
  • Many times the patients asked to exercise by jogging in place or riding a stationary bike and the time it takes for hives to develop is noted.
  • Cholinergic urticaria can be treated by limiting strenuous exercise. It responds well to hydroxyzine.

questions.text: A preterm neonate at 28 weeks developed severe HMD, for which nasal CPAP followed by surfactant was administered using MIST technique. However, due to persistent apneic episodes and pH on ABG below 7.20, the child was intubated and started on mechanical ventilation. Which among the following is the acceptable PaO2 levels to be targeted during mechanical ventilation in this child, ensuring adequate oxygenation and minimal free radical injury?
questions.solution:
The goal of mechanical ventilation in HMD is to improve oxygenation and ventilation without causing pulmonary injury or oxygen toxicity. According to Nelson 21st Ed, acceptable

ranges of ABG values vary significantly among institutions but generally recommended target values are as follows:

  • PaO2 50-70 mm Hg
  • PaCO2 45-65 mm Hg (and higher after the 1st few days when risk of IVH is less)
  • pH 7.20-7.35

Also note that ventilation is done in HMD, rates are kept high, ≥ 60/min while the tidal volume is kept low, about 4-6 ml/kg.

questions.text: A child has recently learnt to start walking holding to furniture, as shown in the picture. What is the age at which this milestone is first attained?
questions.solution: Walking holding onto furniture is called Cruising. Cruising first begins at 11 months of age. Walking with support refers to walking with one hand held and usually begins 1-2 months after the onset of cruising, i.e. at 12-13 months of age.

questions.text: An infant had refractory hypocalcemia in first few weeks of life and was diagnosed with congenital hypoparathyroidism. The child was referred to a pediatric cardiologist for further evaluation. Which other clinical manifestation will often be present in such a child?
questions.solution: The features are suggestive of 22q11 deletion syndrome, also called DiGeorge Syndrome. The 22q11 deletion syndrome is characterized by aplasia or hypoplasia of the thymus and parathyroid glands: this results from dysmorphogenesis of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches during early embryogensis. Other organs that are formed during the same time period are frequently affected as well. Facial abnormalities, esophageal atresia, bifid uvula, and congenital heart disease are some of the anomalies associated with this syndrome. Patients with complete 22q11 deletion syndrome have problems early in life with increased susceptibility to infectious agents such as viruses and fungi. Recurrent candidiasis is a common manifestation in first few months of life.

  • Admit the child, ensure oxygenation
  • Ideal fluid: RL in 5% Dextrose. If not available, N/2 saline in 5% Dextrose or simply RL can also be used.
  • In first hour, give 15 ml/kg as infusion over one hour, while doing strict monitoring
  • If child shows improvement, give another 15 ml/kg over next one hour
  • After this, shift to low-osmolarity ORS 5-10 ml/kg/hr either orally or through nasogastric tube
  • In case of poor response at any stage, individualise therapy and consider ionotropic support.

questions.text: Pick the right answer when 2 screening tests are done in series:
questions.solution:
Sensitivity: Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who have the disease (Cases).

Specificity: Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who don't have the disease (healthy).

Positive predictive value (PPV): Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who have the disease, out of all those who test positive on a screening test.

Negative predictive value (NPV): Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who don't have the disease, out of all those who test negative on a screening test.

Screening tests used in the series: where the result of the first test determines whether to run the second test or not.

Screening tests used in parallel: where the second test is independently performed regardless of what the first test result is. And, both are done at the same time.

If multiple tests are applied in series, the specificity & PPV will increase, the sensitivity & NPV will decrease.

If multiple tests are applied in Parallel, the sensitivity & NPV will increase, the specificity & PPV will decrease.

questions.text: What are the uses of instrument shown in image below?
questions.solution:
• The apparatus shown in the picture above represents pulse oximeter.
  • Pulse oximetry is a non-invasive method for monitoring a person's oxygen saturation (SO2). Its reading of SpO2 (peripheral oxygen saturation) is not always identical to the reading of SaO2 (arterial oxygen saturation) from arterial blood gas analysis, but the two are correlated well enough that the safe, convenient, noninvasive, inexpensive pulse oximetry method is valuable for measuring oxygen saturation in clinical use.
  • In its most common (transmissive) application mode, a sensor device is placed on a thin part of the patient's body, usually a fingertip or earlobe, or in the case of an infant, across a foot. The device passes two wavelengths of light through the body part to a photodetector.It measures the changing absorbance at each of the wavelengths allowing it to determine the absorbances due to the pulsing arterial blood alone, excluding venous blood, skin, bone, muscle, fat, and (in most cases) nail polish.Less commonly, reflectance pulse oximetry is used as an alternative to transmissive pulse oximetry described above.
  • This method does not require a thin section of the person's body and is therefore well suited to a universal application such as the feet, forehead, and chest, but it also has some limitations.

questions.text: Identify the Symbol shown in the photograph:
questions.solution:
Biological hazards(also known as biohazards).

It refer to biological substances that pose a threat to the health of living organisms, primarily that of humans.

This can include medical waste or samples of a microorganism, virus or toxin (from a biological source) that can affect human health. It can also include substances harmful to other animals.

Levels of biohazard
The United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) categorizes various diseases in levels of biohazard, Level 1 being minimum risk and Level 4 being extreme risk.

Biohazard Level 1: Bacteria and viruses including Bacillus subtilis, canine hepatitis, Escherichia coli, varicella (chicken pox), as well as some cell cultures and non-infectious bacteria.

Biohazard Level 2: Bacteria and viruses that cause only mild disease to humans, or are difficult to contract via aerosol in a lab setting, such as hepatitis A, B, and C, some influenza A strains, Lyme disease, salmonella, mumps, measles, scrapie, dengue fever, HIV.

Biohazard Level 3: Bacteria and viruses that can cause severe to fatal disease in humans, but for which vaccines or other treatments exist, such as anthrax, West Nile virus, Venezuelan equine encephalitis, SARS virus, MERS coronavirus, hantaviruses, tuberculosis, typhus, Rift Valley fever, Rocky Mountain spotted fever, yellow fever, and malaria.

Biohazard Level 4: Viruses that cause severe to fatal disease in humans, and for which vaccines or other treatments are not available, such as Bolivian and Argentine hemorrhagic fevers, Marburg virus, Ebola virus, Lassa fever virus, Crimean–Congo hemorrhagic fever, and other hemorrhagic diseases and rishibola. Currently there are no bacteria classified at this level.

questions.text: Which of the following is usually present in neuromyelitis optica?
questions.solution:
NEUROMYELITIS OPTICA

  • Immune mediated demyelinating disorder.
  • Characterised by severe myelopathy that is typically longitudinally extensive (means that the lesion spans three or more vertebral segments).
  • Associated with optic neuritis that is often bilateral and may precede or follow myelitis by weeks or months and also by brainstem and in some cases hypothalamic involvement.
  • Recurrent myelitis without optic nerve involvement can also occur.
  • CSF studies reveal a variable mononuclear pleocytosis of upto several hundred cells per microliter. UNLIKE MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS, CSF OLIGOCLONAL BANDS ARE ABSENT.
  • Diagnostic serum autoantibodies against the water channel protein aquaporin-4 are present in 60-70% of patients .
  • May be associated with SLE and antiphospholipid antibodies as well as with other systemic autoimmune diseases.
  • Rare cases are of paraneoplastic origin.
  • Treatment is with glucocorticoids and for refractory cases plasma exchange.
  • Preliminary studies suggest that treatment with azathioprine? mycophenylate, or anti-CD20 (anti-B cell) monoclonal antibody may protect against subsequent relapses; treatment for 5 years or longer is generally recommended.

questions.text: Regarding parenteral nutrition in the critically ill patient Which is true.?
questions.solution:
In general enteral feeding is successful if feed is running at greater than or equal to 40ml/hr with 4- hourly aspirates totalling <250ml. When enteral feeding is unsuccessful, parenteral nutrition should be considered.

Studies have shown that survival of critically ill patients is best among patients who receive 33-66% of estimated nutritional needs .

Parenteral nutrition is usually administered through a dedicated lumen of a central venous catheter or through a peripherally inserted central catheter. Low osmolality feeds can, however, be administered through a peripheral venous line.

Protein is administered to replace nitrogen losses and prevent further skeletal muscle breakdown; calculation of actual nitrogen balance is difficult so administration of 0.13-0.24g/kg/day of nitrogen is suggested. This usually equates to 1g/kg/day of protein.

Trace elements are not present in commercially produced parenteral nutrition solutions for stability reasons and therefore must be prescribed separately.

choices.text: Setting an extrinsic positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) less than intrinsic PEEP will reduce elastic work of the respiratory system.
One risk of applying PEEP is a reduction in oxygen delivery (DO2).
A decelerating flow pattern is seen in volume-controlled ventilation
The difference between peak and plateau pressures is greater with volume-controlled ventilation than pressure-controlled ventilation.

questions.text: Regarding the mechanics of positive pressure ventilation, all are true except
questions.solution:
Total positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) is an increase in the end expiratory pressure. It is made up of intrinsic PEEP (PEEPi, an increase in the static recoil pressure of the respiratory system, usually due to airflow obstruction) and extrinsic PEEP (PEEPe, positive pressure applied to the expiratory limb of the circuit). During spontaneous ventilation, work must be done to overcome PEEPi before airflow can occur. Applying PEEPe

less than the PEEPi will reduce this elastic work required to initiate airflow. PEEP maintains recruitment of collapsed lung, increases functional residual capacity and minimises intra-pulmonary shunt, thus improving oxygenation. PEEP reduces venous return and therefore cardiac output; oxygen delivery may therefore fall despite an improvement in oxygenation.

PEEP must be titrated to achieve a balance between oxygenation and haemodynamic optimisation.because when peep increases more than optimal value, perfusion to alveoli compromise..

Volume-controlled ventilation (VCV) delivers a constant flow and pressure increases linearly until a peak pressure is achieved. Pressure-controlled ventilation (PCV) produces a decelerating flow pattern .

The peak pressure (Ppk) achieved during VCV is dependent on the elastic and resistive properties of the respiratory system. When an end-inspiratory pause is added, airways and tissue resistance dissipate and the pressure falls to reach a plateau pressure (Pplat). In PCV this resistance dissipates during inspiration so that Ppk and Pplat are equal, and thus an end-inspiratory pause is not usually required to measure Pplat.

questions.text: Which of the following is not derived from dorsal mesenteric (pancreatic) bud?
questions.solution:
• Pancreas develops from two pancreatic buds :
  1. i) Dorsal pancreatic bud:
  • It is larger and most of the pancreas is derived from it i.e. most of the head, and whole neck, body & tail.
  1. ii) Ventral pancreatic bud:
  • It is smaller and forms lower part of the head of pancreas including uncinate process.
  • During 7th week of development, the ventral and dorsal pancreatic buds fuse to form a single pancreatic mass.
  • After the fusion of ventral and dorsal pancreatic buds, their ducts develop cross communications
  • Final duct system is formed as below -
  1. i) Main pancreatic duct (Duct of Wirsung) is formed by the duct of ventral bud, distal part of duct of dorsal bud and an oblique communication between the two. The main pancreatic duct joins the bile duct to form hepatopancreatic ampulla that enters the 2nd part of duodenum at major duodenal papilla.
  2. ii) Accessory pancreatic duct(Duct of Santorini) is formed by the proximal part of the duct of dorsal bud. It opens into 2nd part duodenum at minor duodenal papilla that is located 2 cm proximal (cranial) to major duodenal papilla.

(Ref: IB Singh 7th /ep. 283)

questions.text: A patient comes to your clinic whom you operated for obstructed indirect Left Inguinal hernia one month ago. He says 'It has been over four months from the surgery and I still have much discomfort in the lower abdomen with pain radiating down my private parts.Inside of my thigh is numb and it burns when touched.Which nerve is most likely to be damaged ?
questions.solution:
• Ilioinguinal neuralgia is one of the most common causes of lower abdominal and pelvic pain.

Course of Ilioinguinal nerve:

  • The ilioinguinal nerve is a mixed nerve originating from the anterior rami of T12 and L1 nerve roots. It emerges near the lateral border of the psoas major muscle and goes inferior through the anterior abdominal wall, being sub-peritoneal and anterior to the quadratus lumborum muscle until it reaches the iliac crest.
  • Then the ilioinguinal nerve goes through the transverse abdominis and the internal oblique muscles. It becomes superficial by passing through the superficial inguinal ring anterior to the spermatic cord.

Innervation:

  1. Supplies Motor innervation to:
  2. Transverse abdominis and
  3. Internal oblique muscles.
  4. Carries sensory information from:
  • Anterior surface of the scrotum and root of the penis in males or labia majora and mons pubis in females
  • A small area of the upper anteromedial thigh.

Clinical Significance:

Because of its long course, entrapment or injury of the nerve after lower abdomen surgeries is common.

In Ilioinguinal neuralgia, patients can complain of burning pain, paresthesia, and abnormal sensation in the area supplied by the nerve - over the lower abdomen that radiates to the genitalia and into the inner thigh.

questions.text: Regarding the diagnosis of brainstem death, true statement is
questions.solution:
A summary of the tests to be undertaken are as follows:

  • The pupils are fixed and do not respond to sharp changes in light intensity (mesencephalon, II and III) — dilatation not necessarily present.
  • There is no corneal reflex (pons, V and VII).
  • The oculo-vestibular reflexes are absent (pons, VIII, III, IV, VI).
  • No motor responses within the cranial nerve distribution in response to stimulation of any somatic area.
  • There is no cough reflex response to bronchial stimulation by a suction catheter placed down the trachea to the carina, or gag response to stimulation of the posterior pharynx with a spatula (medulla, IX, X).
  • There is no evidence of spontaneous respiration or respiratory effort during the apnoea test.

Spinal reflexes to a sternal rub can still occur and do not signify brainstem function. Measurement of visual evoked responses is not required for confirmation of brainstem death.

questions.text: Which of the following agents is not in the acute therapy of aortic dissection ?
questions.solution:
Medical therapy should be initiated as soon as the diagnosis of aortic dissection is considered. The patient should be admitted to an intensive care unit for hemodynamic monitoring. Unless hypotension is present, therapy should be aimed at reducing cardiac contractility and systemic arterial pressure, and thus shear stress. For acute dissection, unless contraindicated, β-adrenergic blockers should be administered parenterally, using intravenous propranolol, metoprolol, or the short-acting esmolol to achieve a heart rate of ~60 beats/min. This should be accompanied by sodium nitroprusside infusion to lower systolic blood pressure to ≤120 mmHg. Labetalol , a drug with both β- and α-adrenergic blocking properties, also may be used as a parenteral agent in acute therapy for dissection.

The calcium channel antagonists verapamil and diltiazem may be used intravenously if nitroprusside or β-adrenergic blockers cannot be employed. The addition of a parenteral ACE inhibitor such as enalaprilat to a β-adrenergic blocker also may be considered. Isolated use of a direct vasodilator such as hydralazine is contraindicated because these agents can increase hydraulic shear and may propagate the dissection.

Reference: Harrison 20th edition page 1921

questions.text: A 8 year old boy subnormal intelligence was brought to the OPD with history of self mutilation. Choose the false statement regarding this condition ?
questions.solution:
The Salvage pathway ensures recycling/reutilisation of purines formed by degradation of nucleotides. In Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, this pathway is defective.

Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome

  • X-linked disorder of purine metabolism.
  • There is deficiency of Hypoxanthine Guanine Phosphoribosyl Transferase (HGPRTase).
  • Thus the salvage pathway is decreased resulting in accumulation of PRPP and decreased level of inhibitory purine nucleotides.
  • Characterised by self mutilation, mental retardation, excessive uric acid and nephrolithiasis.
  • Gout develops in later life.
  • The neurological manifestations is because of the fact that the brain is dependent on the salvage pathway for the requirements of IMP and GMP.

  • Cardinal feature is the accumulation in the lysosomes of centrilobular hepatocytes of dark,coarsely granular pigment. As a result, the liver may be grossly black in appearance.

Regarding other options :
Option A: Sweat test is highly specific for Cystic fibrosis. Malfunction of CFTR leads to diminished chloride uptake from sweat duct lumen and thus sweat emerges on the skin with markedly elevated levels of chloride.

Option B: In vivo measurement of ion transport across the nasal airways can serve as specific test for cystic fibrosis. Elevated transepithelial charge separation across airway epithelial tissue is highly specific.

Option C: Organisms routinely cultured from sputum of cystic fibrosis patients are Staph aureus, H.influenzae and Pseudomonas aeruginosa

questions.text: A 48 year old female diagnosed with SLE at 20 years of age and on irregular medications, now presents with pain and deformity of both hands. Examination showed that the deformity shown in figure below is manually reversible on applying force. What is the likely reason for the deformity ?
questions.solution:
In Jaccoud’s arthropathy, the deformities are reducible and result mainly from soft-tissue abnormalities, such as laxity of ligaments, fibrosis of the capsule, and muscular imbalance, rather than from destruction of the bone of joints, as occurs in rheumatoid arthritis (in which deformity is not reducible)

Jaccoud's arthropathy was initially described in relation to rheumatic fever, but now more cases are seen in association with SLE, other connective tissue diseases and neoplasias

questions.text: Osborn waves on ECG occur in :
questions.solution:
ECG changes in hypothermia

  • Most characteristic ECG sign of hypothermia is the ‘J’ or Junctional wave.
  • J wave is a hump like deflection which occurs at the junction of the distal limb of QRS complex with the ST segment .
  • The amplitude of this deflection is proportional to the degree of hypothermia.
  • Distinctive convex elevation of the J point in hypothermia is known as Osborn wave.


Other ECG changes associated with hypothermia are :

  • Sinus bradycardia
  • First and second degree AV block
  • Ectopic rhythms
  • Prolongation of QRS complex duration
  • Prolongation of QT interval

questions.text: All of the following constitute Beck's triad except :
questions.solution:
Beck’s triad is a feature of cardiac tamponade.Pericardial knock is not a component of the triad.

CARDIAC TAMPONADE

  • Results from fluid accumulation in the pericardial space in a quantity sufficient to cause serious obstruction of the inflow of blood into the ventricles.
  • Quantity of fluid necessary to produce cardiac tamponade may be as small as 200 ml when the fluid accumulates rapidly to as much as >2000 ml in slowly developing effusions when the pericardium has had the opportunity to stretch and adapt to an increasing volume.
  • Causes
    -Most common causes of are idiopathic pericarditis and pericarditis secondary to
    neoplastic disease.
    -May also result from bleeding into the pericardial space after leakage from an aortic
    dissection,cardiac operations,trauma and treatment of patients with acute pericarditis
    with anticoagulants.
  • Three principal features seen in severe cardiac tamponade are together known as
    Beck’s triad:
    -Hypotension.
    -Soft or absent heart sounds.
    -Jugular venous distension with a prominent x descent but an absent
    y descent.
  • ECG findings

-Reduced voltage and electrical alternans.

-Reduced voltage is non-specific and can be caused by a variety of other conditions
(eg:emphysema,infiltrative myocardial disease,pneumothorax)

-Electrical alternans means beat to beat variation in both the amplitude and axis of the
QRS complex.

-It occurs due to large amplitude rhythmic swinging of the heart within the pericardial
sac, in presence of a large pericardial effusion.

-A minimum of 200 ml of fluid is requiredfor manifestation of electrical < br / > & nbsp;alternans. < br / > -Electrical alternans is specific and pathognomonic,but relatively insensitive. < /p>

PERICARDIAL KNOCK < /strong>

< ul > < li > Also known as & ldquo;third heart sound of constrictive pericarditis & rdquo;. < /li>
  • Early diastolic sound best heard at the left sternal border or the cardiac apex.
    • < li > Corresponds to the early,abrupt cessation of ventricular filling by the thick,adherent and fibrosed pericardium. < /li>
  • Occurs slightly earlier and has higher frequency than a typical third heart sound.
    • < /ul>

questions.text: The following drugs are used in the treatment of acute severe asthma except:
questions.solution:
Treatment of Acute Severe Asthma

  • High concentration of oxygen via face mask to achieve oxygen saturation of >90%.
  • Mainstay of treatment are high doses of SABA given either by nebulizer or via a metered-dose inhaler with a spacer.
  • ln severely ill patients with impending respiratory failure, i.v beta2-agonists may be given.
  • A nebulized anticholinergic may be added if there is not a satisfactory response to beta 2-agonists alone, as there are additive effects.
  • In patients who are refractory to inhaled therapies, a slow infusion of aminophylline may be effective,but it is important to monitor blood levels? especially if patients have already been treated with oral theophylline.
  • Magnesium sulfate given intravenously or by nebulizer is effective when added to inhaled beta 2-agonists,and is relatively well tolerated but is not routinely recommended.
  • Prophylactic intubation may be indicated for impending respiratory failure,when the PC02 is normal or rises.
  • For patients with respiratory failure,it is necessary to intubate and institute ventilation. These patients may benefit from an anesthetic such as halothane if they have not responded to conventional bronchodilators.
  • Sedatives should never be given because they may depress ventilation.
  • Antibiotics should not be used routinely unless there are signs of pneumonia.

OMALIZUMAB

  • Blocking antibody that neutralizes circulating IgE without binding to cell-bound IgE and,thus, inhibits IgE-mediated reactions.
  • Reduce the number of exacerbations in patients with severe asthma and may improve asthma control. However, it is not useful in treatment of aute severe asthma.
  • Very expensive and is only suitable for highly selected patients who are not controlled on maximal doses of inhaler therapy and have a circulating IgE within a specified range.
  • Usually given as a subcutaneous injection every 2-4 weeks.

questions.text: Hyperekplexia occurs due to mutations in :
questions.solution: Hyperekplexia(startle syndrome) is characterised by marked muscular hypertonia and severe jerks induced by sound or tactile stimuli. Classic hyperekplexia is caused by genetic mutations in a number of different genes, all of which play an important role in glycine neurotransmission.

questions.text: Identify the stage of pericarditis from the ECG ?
questions.solution:
Stage I: ST elevation in all leads and PR depression
Stage II: pseudonormalisation
Stage III: inverted T-waves
Stage IV: normalisation

questions.text: The most common form of acute kidney injury is due to :
questions.solution:
The causes of acute kidney injury can be classified into three major categories:

  • Pre-renal azotemia
  • Intrinsic renal parenchymal disease
  • Postrenal obstruction


Among these causes, pre-renal azotemia is the most common form of AKI.

questions.solution:
Rhomboid crystals with weakly positive birefringence is seen in pseudogout.

questions.text: A lesion in the area highlighted in green is likely to produce ?
questions.solution:
The area highlighted in green is the subthalamic nucleus, lesion of which produces hemiballismus.
Ballism is a violent form of choreiform movement composed of wild, flinging, large-amplitude movements most frequently affecting proximal limb muscles on one side of the body (hemiballism). The move- ments may only affect one limb (monoballism) or, more exceptionally, both upper or lower limbs (paraballism). The movements may be so severe as to cause exhaustion, dehydration, local injury, and, in extreme cases, death. The most common cause is a partial lesion (infarct or hemorrhage) in the subthalamic nucleus, but in 30–40% of cases the lesion is found in the putamen, thalamus, or parietal cortex.
